awd_titl_txt: Information Security and Assurance for Technology Leadership and Innovation
awd_abstract_narration:
The Johns Hopkins University Information Security Institute (JHUISI) proposes to add four new cohorts of graduate students to their existing CyberCorps(R) Scholarship for Service (SFS) program in cybersecurity. JHUISI offers a Masters of Science in Security Informatics (MSSI) program focusing on immersive educational experience and often combining expertise in other areas such as healthcare or project management. The MSSI program and associated dual-degree programs are based on an integration of courses, labs, research projects, and internships stemming from the various academic cultures represented the Carey School of Business, Bloomberg School of Public Health, School of Medicine, Krieger School of Arts and Sciences, and Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies at the Johns Hopkins University. These partnerships developed a unique interdisciplinary framework supporting educational cross-training in cybersecurity technologies relative to various application areas.  

SFS students will complete the MSSI degree program with an option to earn a dual degree in Computer Science, Applied Math and Statistics, Health Sciences, or National Security Studies. These dual masters programs have proven to be valuable for various federal agencies.  In particular, the project provides exposure to the increasingly critical field of healthcare security to a new generation of cybersecurity professionals. The relevance of this area is underscored at the federal and state health infrastructures by mandates to broaden utilization of information technology in the delivery of healthcare while protecting the security and privacy of health information exchanges and on-line databases. SFS students will help with the critical challenge of establishing trusted national healthcare information networks to unify health and medical computing infrastructures, streamline healthcare monitoring and delivery, and accelerate research and dissemination of health and medical data while assuring that privacy is systemically protected. The project will conduct a focused outreach to assure diversity by leveraging existing partnerships with HBCUs and MSIs.

por.por_cntn:
Traditionally security education relies heavily on textbooks, simulations, and in-house lab experiments and as a consequence, students are exposed to very few real-world problems. Also, cybersecurity education has difficulty keeping up with rapidly evolving security threats and computing technologies. These two challenges, hamper the mission of educating students in state-of-the-art cybersecurity practices.

To address these issues, Johns Hopkins University Information Security Institute (JHUISI) is embarking on a real-world project-based learning mechanism where faculty, partner corporations, and national lab scientists work closely to orchestrate course modules with real-world capstone projects that provide students with immersive learning experiences throughout their program of study.

  • First, the close collaboration between faculty and practitioners fosters a team-teaching scheme that is responsive to real-world practices and labor market demand.
  • Second, the immersion in real-world capstone projects complements traditional classroom teaching by motivating a student to study a subject as deeply as possible starting from the beginning of the program of study.
  • Third, the student project feedback and research results enable an agile curriculum development lifecycle through regular revisions and updates of course materials.

The primary goal of this project is to address the national need for information security specialists with skill sets that are ideally suited to prepare specialists with careers in information security technological leadership. JHUISI recruits and awards funding through the SFS program to highly qualified applicants who enroll in the Master of Science in Security Informatics (MSSI) program to provide government employers with bright and thriving individuals in a myriad of security engineering roles.﻿ To fulfill this commitment The MSSI program is continuously staffed with some of the top leaders in the field of information security and rigorously fosters connections with corporations and government agencies to craft a diversified academic and research portfolio for maximum exposure to real-life scenarios and applications pertinent to society today.

Over the project period, twelve SFS scholars successfully completed their program of study. They were prepared with a range of technology, policy, management, and health courses and seminars. Each of them actively participated in a capstone project supported by a team of JHUISI faculty, research and administrative staff, and external partners. Several scholars worked on additional research projects with the JHUISI faculty. These projects resulted in research reports and publications. All of them were successfully placed in government departments, agencies, and R&D centers.

The JHUISI team engaged in regular exchanges and information distribution with other researchers and practitioners in conferences and meetings about cybersecurity security research and education generated in this project, including conference publications and presentations.


Last Modified: 11/12/2023
Modified by: Anton Dahbura
